only happy to themselves, but happy to their Fami<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>lies.
But, said the Empress, if you glory so much
in your Honesty and Vertue, how comes it that you
plead for Dishonest and Wicked persons, in your
Writings? The Duchess answered, It was only to
shew her Wit, not her Nature.
At last the Empress arrived into the Blazing-world,
and coming to her Imperial Palace, you may sooner
imagine than expect that I should express the joy
which the Emperor had at her safe return; for he lo<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ved
her beyond his Soul; and there was no love
lost, for the Empress equal'd his Affection with no
less love to him. After the time of rejoicing with
each other, the Duchess's Soul begg'd leave to return
to her Noble Lord: But the Emperor desired, that
before she departed, she would see how he had em<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ployed
his time in the Empress's absence; for he had
built Stables and Riding-Houses, and desired to
have Horses of Manage, such as, according to the
Empress's Relation, the Duke of <hi>Newcastle</hi> had:
The Emperor enquired of the Duchess, the Form and
Structure of her Lord and Husband's Stables and Ri<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ding-House.
The Duchess answer'd his Majesty, That
they were but plain and ordinary; but, said she, had
my Lord Wealth, I am sure he would not spare it,
in rendring his Buildings as Noble as could be made.
Hereupon the Emperor shewed the Duchess the Sta<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>bles
he had built, which were most stately and mag<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>nificent;
among the rest, there was one double Sta<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ble
that held a Hundred Horses on a side, the main
Building was of Gold, lined with several sorts of
precious Materials; the Roof was Arched with A<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>gats,
the sides of the Walls were lined with Cor<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>nelian,
the Floor was paved with Amber, the Man<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>gers
were Mother of Pearl; the Pillars, as also the mid<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>dle
Isle or Walk of the Stables, were of Crystal; the
Front and Gate was of Turquois, most neatly cut
and carved. The Riding-House was lined with Sa<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>phirs,
Topases, and the like; the Floor was all of
Golden-Sand so finely sifted, that it was extreamly
soft, and not in the least hurtful to the Horses feet, and
the Door and Frontispiece was of Emeralds curiously
carved.
After the view of these Glorious and Magnificent
Buildings, which the Duchess's Soul was much delight<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ed
withall, she resolved to take her leave; but the Em<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>peror
desired her to stay yet some short time more, for
they both loved her company so well, that they were
unwilling to have her depart so soon: Several Confer<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ences
and Discourses pass'd between them; amongst
the rest, the Emperor desir'd her advice how to set up a
Theatre for Plays. The Duchess confessed her Igno<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>rance
in this Art, telling his Majesty that she knew no<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>thing
of erecting Theatres or Scenes, but what she had
by an Immaterial Observation, when she was with the
Empress's Soul in the chief City of <hi>E.</hi> Entring into
one of their Theatres, whereof the Empress could
give as much account to his Majesty, as her self. But
both the Emperor and Empress told the Duchess,
That she could give directions how to make Plays. The
Duchess answered, That she had as little skill to form a
Play after the Mode, as she had to paint or make a
Scene for shew. But you have made Plays, re<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>plied
the Empress: Yes, answered the Duchess, I
intended them for Plays; but the Wits of these
present times condemned them as uncapable of being
represented or acted, because they were not made up
according to the Rules of Art; though I dare say,
That the Descriptions are as good as any they have
writ. The Emperor asked, Whether the Property
of Plays were not to describe the several Humours,
Actions and Fortunes of Mankind? 'Tis so, answered
the Duchess. VVhy then, replied the Emperor, the
natural Humours, Actions and Fortunes of Man<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>kind,
are not done by the Rules of Art: But, said
the Duchess, it is the Art and Method of our VVits
to despise all Descriptions of VVit, Humour, Acti<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ons
and Fortunes that are without such Artificial
Rules. The Emperor asked, Are those good Plays
that are made so Methodically and Artificially? The
Duchess answer'd, They were Good according to
the Judgment of the Age, or Mode of the Nation,
but not according to her Judgment: for truly, said
she, in my Opinion, their Plays will prove a Nur<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>sery
of whining Lovers, and not an Academy or
School for VVise, VVitty, Noble and well-beha<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ved
men. But I, replied the Emperor, desire such
a Theatre as may make wise Men; and will have
such Descriptions as are Natural, not Artificial. If
your Majesty be of that Opinion, said the Duchess's
Soul, then my Playes may be acted in your Blazing-World,
when they cannot be acted in the Blink<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ing-World
of Wit; and the next time I come to
visit your Majesty, I shall endeavour to order your
Majesty's Theatre, to present such Playes as my
Wit is capable to make. Then the Empress told
the Duchess, That she loved a foolish <gap reason="illegible: overwritten" extent="2 letters">
<desc>••</desc>
</gap>rse added
to a wise Play. The Duchess answered, That no
World in Nature had fitter Creatures for it than
the Blazing-World: for, said she, the Lowse<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>men,
the Bird-men, the Spider- and Fox-men, the
Ape-men and Satyrs appear in a <gap reason="illegible: overwritten" extent="2 letters">
<desc>••</desc>
</gap>rse extraordinary
pleasant.
Hereupon both the Emperor and Empress intreated
the Duchess's Soul to stay so long with them,
till she had ordered her Theatre, and made Playes
and <gap reason="illegible: overwritten" extent="2 letters">
<desc>••</desc>
</gap>rses fit for them; for they onely wanted that
sort of Recreation: but the Duchess's Soul begg'd
their Majesties to give her leave to go into her Na<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>tive
World; for she long'd to be with her dear
Lord and Husband, promising, that after a short
time she would return again. Which being grant<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ed,
though with much difficulty, she took her leave
with all Civility and Respect, and so departed from
their Majesties.
After the Duchess's return into her own body,
she entertained her Lord (when he was pleased to
hear such kind of Discourses) with Foreign Rela<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>tions;
but he was never displeased to hear of the Em<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>press's
kind Commendations, and of the Chara<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>cters
she was pleased to give of him to the Empe<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ror.
Amongst other Relations, she told him all what
had past between the Empress, and the several Mo<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>narchs
of that VVorld whither she went with the Em<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>press;
and how she had subdued them to pay Tri<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>bute
and Homage to the Monarch of that Nation
or Kingdom to which she owed both her Birth
and Education. She also related to her Lord what
Magnificent Stables and Riding-Houses the Empe<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ror
had built, and what fine Horses were in the Bla<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>zing-world,
of several shapes and sizes, and how
exact their shapes were in each sort, and of many
various Colours, and fine Marks, as if they had
been painted by Art, with such Coats or Skins, that
they had a far greater gloss and smoothness than Sat<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>tin;
and were there but a passage out of the Blazing-world
into this, said she, you should not one<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ly
have some of those Horses, but such Mate<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>rials
as the Emperor has, to build your Stables
and Riding-Houses withall; and so much Gold, that
I should never repine at your Noble and Generous
Gifts. The Duke smilingly answered her, That he
was sorry there was no Passage between those two
VVorlds; but, said he, I have always found an Ob<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>struction
to my Good Fortunes.
One time the Duchess chanced to discourse with
some of her acquaintance, of the Empress of the Bla<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>zing-world,
who asked her what Pastimes and Recrea<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>tions
her Majesty did most delight in? The Du<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>chess
answered, That she spent most of her time in the
study of Natural Causes and Effects, which was her
chief delight and pastime; and that she loved to dis<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>course
sometimes with the most Learned persons of that
World: And to please the Emperor and his Nobles,
who were all of the Royal Race, she went often a<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>broad
to take the air, but seldom in the day-time, al<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ways
at night, if it might be called Night; for, said
she, the Nights there, are as light as Days, by reason
of the numerous Blazing-Starrs, which are very splen<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>dorous,
onely their Light is whiter than the Sun's
Light; and as the Sun's Light is hot, so their Light is
cool; not so cool as our twinkling Starr-light, nor
is their Sun-light so hot as ours, but more tempe<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>rate:
And that part of the Blazing-world where the
Empress resides, is always clear, and never subject to
any Storms, Tempests, Fogs or Mists, but has onely
refreshing-Dews that nourish the Earth: The air of it
is sweet and temperate, and, as I said before, as much
light in the Sun's absence, as in its presence, which
makes that time we call Night, more pleasant there
than the Day: And sometimes the Empress goes
abroad by Water in Barges, sometimes by Land in
Chariots, and sometimes on Horse-back; her Royal
Chariots are very Glorious, the Body is one intire
green Diamond; the four small Pillars that bear up
the Top-cover, are four white Diamonds, cut in the
form thereof; the top or roof of the Chariot, is one in<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>tire
blew Diamond, and at the four corners are great
springs of Rubies; the Seat is made of Cloth of Gold,
stuffed with Ambergreece beaten small: the Chariot
is drawn by Twelve Unicorns, whose Trappings are
all Chains of Pearl; and as for her Barges, they are
onely of Gold. Her Guard of State (for she needs
none for security, there being no Rebels or Ene<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>mies)
consists of Giants, but they seldom wait on
their Majesties abroad, because their extraordinary
height and bigness does hinder their prospect. Her En<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>tertainment
when she is upon the Water, is the Mu<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>sick
of the Fish- and Bird-men; and by Land are Horse
and Foot-matches; for the Empress takes much de<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>light
in making Race-matches with the Emperor, and
the Nobility; some Races are between the Fox- and
Ape-men, which sometimes the Satyrs strive to out-run;
and some are between the Spider-men and Lice-men.
Also there are several Flight-matches, between
the several sorts of Bird-men, and the several sorts of
Fly-men; and Swimming-matches, between the se<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>veral
sorts of Fish-men. The Emperor, Empress,
and their Nobles, take also great delight to have Colla<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>tions;
for in the Blazing-world; there are most deli<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>cious
Fruits of all sorts, and some such as in this
World were never seen nor tasted; for there are most
tempting sorts of Fruit: After their Collations are
ended, they Dance; and if they be upon the Wa<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ter,
they dance upon the Water, there lying so ma<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ny
Fish-men so close and thick together, as they can
dance very evenly and easily upon their backs, and
need not fear drowning. Their Musick, both Vocal
and Instrumental, is according to their several places:
Upon the Water, it is of Water-Instruments, as shells
filled with Water, and so moved by Art, which is a
very sweet and delightful harmony; and those Dan<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ces
which they dance upon the Water, are, for the
most part, such as we in this World call <hi>Swimming-Dances,</hi>
where they do not lift up their feet high: In
Lawns, or upon Plains, they have Wind-Instruments,
but much better than those in our World: And when
they dance in the Woods, they have Horn-Instru<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ments,
which although they are of a sort of Wind-In<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>struments,
yet they are of another Fashion than the
former: In their Houses they have such Instruments
as are somewhat like our Viols, Violins, Theorboes,
Lutes, Citherins, Gittars, Harpsichords, and the like;
but yet so far beyond them, that the difference cannot
well be exprest; and as their places of Dancing, and
their Musick is different, so is their manner or way of
Dancing. In these and the like Recreations, the
Emperor, Empress, and the Nobility pass their
time.
<div type="epilogue">
<head>THE
EPILOGUE
TO THE
READER</head>
BY this Poetical Description, you may perceive, that
my ambition is not onely to be Empress, but Autho<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ress
of a whole World; and that the Worlds I have made,
both the <hi>Blazing</hi>-and the other <hi>Philosophical</hi> World, men<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>tioned
in the first Part of this <hi>Description,</hi> are framed
and composed of the most pure, that is, the Rational parts of
Matter, which are the parts of my Mind; which Crea<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>tion
was more easily and suddenly effected, than the Con<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>quests
of the two famous Monarchs of the World, <hi>Alexan<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>der</hi>
and <hi>Cesar.</hi> Neither have I made such disturbances,
and caused so many dissolutions of particulars, otherwise na<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>med
deaths, as they did; for I have destroyed but some few
men in a little Boat, which dyed through the extremity of
cold, and that by the hand of Justice, which was necessitated
to punish their crime of stealing away a young and beaute<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>ous
Lady. And in the formation of those Worlds, I take
more delight and glory, than ever <hi>Alexander</hi> or <hi>Cesar</hi> did
in conquering this terrestrial world; and though I have made
my <hi>Blazing-world</hi> a Peaceable World, allowing it but one
Religion, one Language, and one Government; yet could
I make another World, as full of Factions, Divisions and
VVarrs, as this is of Peace and Tranquility; and the Ratio<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>nal
figures of my Mind might express as much courage to
fight, as <hi>Hector</hi> and <hi>Achilles</hi> had; and be as wise as <hi>Nestor,</hi>
as Eloquent as <hi>Ulysses,</hi> and as beautiful as <hi>Hellen.</hi> But I
esteeming Peace before VVarr, VVit before Policy, Hone<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>sty
before Beauty; instead of the figures of <hi>Alexander, Ce<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>sar,
Hector, Achilles, Nestor, Ulysses, Hellen,</hi> &c. chose
rather the figure of Honest <hi>Margaret Newcastle,</hi> which
now I would not change for all this Terrestrial World; and
if any should like the World I have made, and be willing to
be my Subjects, they may imagine themselves such, and
they are such, I mean in their Minds, Fancies or Imagina<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>tions;
but if they cannot endure to be Subjects, they may
create Worlds of their own, and Govern themselves as they
please. But yet let them have a care, not to prove unjust U<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>surpers,
and to rob me of mine: for, concerning the <hi>Philo<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>sophical-world,</hi>
I am Empress of it my self; and as for
the <hi>Blazing-world,</hi> it having an Empress already, who rules
it with great Wisdom and Conduct, which Empress is my
dear Platonick Friend; I shall never prove so unjust, trea<g ref="char:EOLhyphen"/>cherous
and unworthy to her, as to disturb her Government,
much less to depose her from her Imperial Throne, for the
sake of any other, but rather chuse to create another World
for another Friend.
<trailer>FINIS.</trailer>
</body>
</text>
</TEI>
